          V-248613 - OL 8 must not permit direct logons to the root account using remote access via SSH.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248613r858578_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-010550
          Identities:CCI-000770 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-2 (5) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-2 (5).2 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (5))
          Description: Although the communications channel may be encrypted, an additional layer of security is gained by extending the policy of not logging on directly as root. In addition, logging on with a user-specific account provides individual accountability of actions performed on the system. false
          Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to stop users from logging on remotely as the "root" user via SSH.

          Edit the appropriate "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file to uncomment or add the line for the "PermitRootLogin" keyword and set its value to "no":

          PermitRootLogin no

          The SSH daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the SSH daemon, run the following command:

          $ sudo systemctl restart sshd.service
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:160
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-010550 - OL 8 must not permit direct logons to the root account using remote access via SSH.
          Description:Although the communications channel may be encrypted, an additional layer of security is gained by extending the policy of not logging on directly as root. In addition, logging on with a user-specific account provides individual accountability of actions performed on the system.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/etc/ssh/sshd_config:PermitRootLogin == no)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:16000 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/ssh/sshd_config:PermitRootLogin == no
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:16000 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*(?i)PermitRootLogin(?-i)[ \t]+([\w\"]+)[\s]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:16000 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^(no|"no")$'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
          • path equals '/etc/ssh'
          • filename equals 'sshd_config'
          • pattern equals '^\s*(?i)PermitRootLogin(?-i)[ \t]+([\w\"]+)[\s]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'PermitRootLogin yes
            #StrictModes yes'
          • line equals 'PermitRootLogin yes
            #StrictModes yes'
          • subexpression equals 'yes'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.

          V-248617 - OL 8 must prevent files with the setuid and setgid bit set from being executed on the /boot directory.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248617r779417_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-010571
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: The "nosuid" mount option causes the system not to execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
          Fix Text:Configure the "/etc/fstab" to use the "nosuid" option on the /boot directory.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:163
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-010571 - OL 8 must prevent files with the setuid and setgid bit set from being executed on the /boot directory.
          Description:The "nosuid" mount option causes the system not to execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (If /boot is mounted, it is mounted with the nosuid option)
              • false (If /boot is configured in /etc/fstab, it is configured with the nosuid option)
            • false (/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg exists.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:16300 (partition_test)
          Result:false
          Title:If /boot is mounted, it is mounted with the nosuid option
          Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:16300 (partition_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • mount_point must be equal to '/boot'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:16300 (partition_state)

          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', mount_options must be equal to 'nosuid'

          [ false ]
          • mount_point equals '/boot'
          • device equals '/dev/sda1'

          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.

          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:16301 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:If /boot is configured in /etc/fstab, it is configured with the nosuid option
          Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.

          V-248619 - OL 8 must prevent special devices on non-root local partitions.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248619r779423_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-010580
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. The only legitimate location for device files is the /dev directory located on the root partition. false
          Fix Text:Configure the "/etc/fstab" to use the "nodev" option on all non-root local partitions.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:164
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-010580 - OL 8 must prevent special devices on non-root local partitions.
          Description:The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. The only legitimate location for device files is the /dev directory located on the root partition.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Device files are mounted with the nodev option. Mounts on '/' are ignored.)
            • true (Device files are configured in /etc/fstab to use the nodev option. Mounts on '/' are ignored.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:16400 (partition_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Device files are mounted with the nodev option. Mounts on '/' are ignored.
          Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:16400 (partition_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • mount_point must match the pattern '^/\S+$'
          Include Items If:
          • device matches the pattern '^/dev\S*$'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:16400 (partition_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', mount_options must be equal to 'nodev'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • mount_point equals '/boot'
          • device equals '/dev/sda1'
          • uuid equals 'cd381ead-28c2-4659-951d-9ebe628871ca'

          • mount_options equals 'relatime'

          V-248629 - OL 8 must disable the "kernel.core_pattern".

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248629r858629_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-010671
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to disable storing core dumps by adding the following line to a file in the "/etc/sysctl.d" directory:

          kernel.core_pattern = |/bin/false

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          The system configuration files must be reloaded for the changes to take effect. To reload the contents of the files, run the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:168
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-010671 - OL 8 must disable the "kernel.core_pattern".
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.
          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (kernel.core_pattern setting in kernel is set to '|/bin/false'.)
            • false (kernel.core_pattern setting in the sysctl configuration files is set to '|/bin/false', and nothing else)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:16800 (sysctl_test)
          Result:false
          Title:kernel.core_pattern setting in kernel is set to '|/bin/false'.
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:16800 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'kernel.core_pattern'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:16800 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must match the pattern '^\|\s*/bin/false\s*$'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • name equals 'kernel.core_pattern'
          • value equals '|/usr/lib/systemd/systemd-coredump %P %u %g %s %t %c %h %e'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:16801 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:kernel.core_pattern setting in the sysctl configuration files is set to '|/bin/false', and nothing else
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:16803 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:16801 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^\|\s*/bin/false\s*$'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/lib/sysctl.d/50-coredump.conf'
          • path equals '/lib/sysctl.d'
          • filename equals '50-coredump.conf'
          • pattern equals '(?:^|\.*\n)\s*kernel\.core_pattern\s*=\s*(.+)'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals '.

            kernel.core_pattern=|/usr/lib/systemd/systemd-coredump %P %u %g %s %t %c %h %e'
          • line equals '.

            kernel.core_pattern=|/usr/lib/systemd/systemd-coredump %P %u %g %s %t %c %h %e'
          • subexpression equals '|/usr/lib/systemd/systemd-coredump %P %u %g %s %t %c %h %e'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]

          • filename equals '50-coredump.conf'
          • pattern equals '(?:^|\.*\n)\s*kernel\.core_pattern\s*=\s*(.+)'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals '.

            kernel.core_pattern=|/usr/lib/systemd/systemd-coredump %P %u %g %s %t %c %h %e'
          • line equals '.

            kernel.core_pattern=|/usr/lib/systemd/systemd-coredump %P %u %g %s %t %c %h %e'

          V-248632 - OL 8 must disable storing core dumps.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248632r779462_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-010674
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems. false
          Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to disable storing core dumps for all users.

          Add or modify the following line in "/etc/systemd/coredump.conf":

          Storage=none
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:170
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-010674 - OL 8 must disable storing core dumps.
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (storing core dumps is disabled)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17000 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:storing core dumps is disabled
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17000 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/systemd/coredump.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*Storage\s*=\s*(\w*)\s*(?:#.*)?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17000 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'none'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-248633 - OL 8 must disable core dump backtraces.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248633r779465_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-010675
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems. false
          Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to disable core dump backtraces.

          Add or modify the following line in "/etc/systemd/coredump.conf":

          ProcessSizeMax=0
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:171
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-010675 - OL 8 must disable core dump backtraces.
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (core dump backtraces are disabled)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17100 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:core dump backtraces are disabled
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17100 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/systemd/coredump.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*ProcessSizeMax\s*=\s*(\w*)\s*(?:#.*)?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17100 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-248653 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248653r853776_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020011
          Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
          CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
          Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
          Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

          Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

          deny = 3
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:175
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-020011 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.
          Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
            • false (check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the deny setting value)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17500 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17500 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc'
          • filename must be equal to 'os-release'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17501 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than '2'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/os-release'
          • path equals '/etc'
          • filename equals 'os-release'
          • pattern equals '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
          • line equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
          • subexpression equals '8'
          • subexpression equals '8'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          subexpression
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17501 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the deny setting value
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17501 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/faillock.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*deny\s*=\s*([\d]+)\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17500 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '3'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17502 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-248655 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248655r853778_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020013
          Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
          CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
          Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
          Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

          Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

          fail_interval = 900
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:177
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-020013 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.
          Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
            • false (check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the fail_interval setting value)
          Tests:

          Result:false
          Title:The OL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17500 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc'
          • filename must be equal to 'os-release'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17501 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than '2'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/os-release'
          • path equals '/etc'
          • filename equals 'os-release'
          • pattern equals '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:(\d+)\b'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
          • line equals 'CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:oracle:linux:8:8'
          • subexpression equals '8'
          • subexpression equals '8'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          subexpression
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:17701 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the fail_interval setting value
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:17700 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/faillock.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*fail_interval\s*=\s*([\d]+)\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:17700 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '900'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-248657 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must automatically lock an account until the locked account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248657r853780_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020015
          Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
          CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
          Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
          Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to lock an account until released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur in 15 minutes.

          Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

          unlock_time = 0
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:179
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-020015 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must automatically lock an account until the locked account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.
          Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          V-248661 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must prevent system messages from being presented when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248661r853784_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020019
          Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
          CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
          Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the" pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to prevent informative messages from being presented at logon attempts.

          Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

          silent
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:181
          Result:false

          Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the" pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          V-248663 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must log user name information when unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248663r853786_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020021
          Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
          CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
          Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to log user name information when unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

          Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

          audit
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:

          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in "/etc/passwd" and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          V-248665 - OL 8 systems, versions 8.2 and above, must include root when automatically locking an account until the locked account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248665r853788_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020023
          Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
          CCI-002238 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 b)
          Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in /etc/passwd and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to include root when locking an account after three unsuccessful logon attempts occur in 15 minutes.

          Add/modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

          even_deny_root
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416

          Result:false

          Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In OL 8.2, the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the "pam_faillock.so" module.           From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable, a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          V-248674 - OL 8 must have the tmux package installed.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248674r779588_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020039
          Identities:CCI-000056 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 b)
          CCI-000058 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 a)
          Description: A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

          The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

          Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enable a user to initiate a session lock via tmux.

          Install the "tmux" package, if it is not already installed, by running the following command:

          $ sudo yum install tmux
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:187
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-020039 - OL 8 must have the tmux package installed.
          Description:A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

          The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

          Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011

          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (The tmux package is installed)

          V-248675 - OL 8 must enable a user session lock until that user re-establishes access using established identification and authentication procedures for command line sessions.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248675r902786_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020040
          Identities:CCI-000056 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 b)
          CCI-000058 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 a)
          Description: A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

          The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

          Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enable a user to manually initiate a session lock via tmux. This configuration binds the uppercase letter "X" to manually initiate a session lock after the prefix key "Ctrl + b" has been sent. The complete key sequence is thus "Ctrl + b" then "Shift + x" to lock tmux.

          Create a global configuration file "/etc/tmux.conf" and add the following lines:

          set -g lock-command vlock
          bind X lock-session

          Reload tmux configuration to take effect. This can be performed in tmux while it is running:

          $ tmux source-file /etc/tmux.conf
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8os:def:248675
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-020040 - OL 8 must enable a user session lock until that user re-establishes access using established identification and authentication procedures for command line sessions.
          Description:A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

          The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

          Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (The lock-command is set in /etc/tmux.conf)
              • false (The lock-session is bound to X, in /etc/tmux.conf)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23034800 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:The lock-command is set in /etc/tmux.conf
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23034800 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/tmux.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*set\s+-g\s+lock-command\s+vlock\s*(?:#.*)?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23034801 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:The lock-session is bound to X, in /etc/tmux.conf
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23034801 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/tmux.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*bind\s+X\s+lock-session\s*(?:#.*)?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-248676 - OL 8 must ensure session control is automatically started at shell initialization.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248676r880538_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020041
          Identities:CCI-000056 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 b)
          CCI-000058 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 a)
          Description: A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

          The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

          Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to initialize the tmux terminal multiplexer as each shell is called by adding the following lines to a custom.sh shell script in the /etc/profile.d/ directory:

          if [ "$PS1" ]; then
          parent=$(ps -o ppid= -p $$)
          name=$(ps -o comm= -p $parent)
          case "$name" in (sshd|login) tmux ;; esac
          fi

          This setting will take effect at next logon.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:189
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-020041 - OL 8 must ensure session control is automatically started at shell initialization.
          Description:A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

          The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, OL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

          Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/etc/profile.d/*.sh contains a shell script to initialize the tmux terminal multiplexer as each shell is called.)
            • false (The tmux process is running.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:18900 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/profile.d/*.sh contains a shell script to initialize the tmux terminal multiplexer as each shell is called.
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:18900 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc/profile.d'
          • filename must match the pattern '\.sh$'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*if\s+\[\s*"\$PS1"\s*\];\s+then\s+parent=\$\(ps\s+-o\s+ppid=\s+-p\s+\$\$\)\s+name=\$\(ps\s+-o\s+comm=\s+-p\s+\$parent\)\s+case\s+"\$name"\s+in\s+\(sshd\|login\)\s+tmux\s+;;\s+esac\s+fi\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:18901 (process58_test)
          Result:false
          Title:The tmux process is running.
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:18901 (process58_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • command_line must match the pattern '^(/usr/bin/)?tmux\b'
          • pid must be greater than '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-248690 - OL 8 must require the maximum number of repeating characters of the same character class be limited to four when passwords are changed.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248690r858637_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020140
          Identities:CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
          Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "maxclassrepeat" option sets the maximum number of allowed same consecutive characters in the same class in the new password. false
          Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to require the change of the number of repeating characters of the same character class when passwords are changed by setting the "maxclassrepeat" option.

          Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory:

          maxclassrepeat = 4

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:195
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-020140 - OL 8 must require the maximum number of repeating characters of the same character class be limited to four when passwords are changed.
          Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "maxclassrepeat" option sets the maximum number of allowed same consecutive characters in the same class in the new password.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (the maximum number of repeating characters of the same character class must be limited to four when passwords are changed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:19500 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:the maximum number of repeating characters of the same character class must be limited to four when passwords are changed
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:19502 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:19500 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '4'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:19501 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-248692 - OL 8 must require the change of at least four character classes when passwords are changed.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248692r858641_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020160
          Identities:CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
          Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "minclass" option sets the minimum number of required classes of characters for the new password (digits, upper-case, lower-case, others). false
          Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to require the change of at least four character classes when passwords are changed by setting the "minclass" option.

          Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory:

          minclass = 4

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "minclass" option sets the minimum number of required classes of characters for the new password (digits, upper-case, lower-case, others).

          V-248694 - OL 8 passwords for new users or password changes must have a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime restriction in "/etc/shadow".

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248694r779648_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020180
          Identities:CCI-000198 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
          Description: Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse. false
          Fix Text:Configure non-compliant accounts to enforce a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime:

          $ sudo chage -m 1 [user]
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:199
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-020180 - OL 8 passwords for new users or password changes must have a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime restriction in "/etc/shadow".
          Description:Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Root does not have a minimum password age of 0 or blank)
            • false (Non-system users do not have a minimum password age of 0 or blank)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:19900 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Root does not have a minimum password age of 0 or blank
          Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:19900 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/shadow'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^root:[^:]*:[^:]*:0*:'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/shadow'
          • path equals '/etc'
          • filename equals 'shadow'
          • pattern equals '^root:[^:]*:[^:]*:0*:'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'root:!!:19501:0:'
          • line equals 'root:!!:19501:0:'
          • subexpression does not exist
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:19901 (password_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Non-system users do not have a minimum password age of 0 or blank
          Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:19901 (password_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • for username, at least one of the following must be true:
            • username must be equal to 'root'
            • username must be equal to 'bin'
            • username must be equal to 'daemon'
            • username must be equal to 'adm'
            • username must be equal to 'lp'
            • username must be equal to 'sync'
            • username must be equal to 'shutdown'
            • username must be equal to 'halt'
            • username must be equal to 'mail'
            • username must be equal to 'operator'
            • username must be equal to 'games'
            • username must be equal to 'ftp'
            • username must be equal to 'nobody'
            • username must be equal to 'dbus'
            • username must be equal to 'systemd-coredump'
            • username must be equal to 'systemd-resolve'
            • username must be equal to 'tss'
            • username must be equal to 'polkitd'
            • username must be equal to 'unbound'
            • username must be equal to 'chrony'
            • username must be equal to 'sshd'
            • username must be equal to 'vboxadd'
            • username must be equal to 'vagrant'
          Exclude Items If:
          • user_id is less than '1000'
          Exclude Items If:
          • for check = 'all', user_id, all of the following must be true:
            • user_id equals '65534'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • username equals 'vagrant'
          • password equals [MASKED PASSWORD FIELD]
          • user_id equals '1000'
          • group_id equals '1000'
          • gcos equals ''
          • home_dir equals '/home/vagrant'
          • login_shell equals '/bin/bash'
          • last_login equals '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-248695 - OL 8 passwords for new users or password changes must have a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime restriction in "/etc/login.defs".

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248695r858592_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020190
          Identities:CCI-000198 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
          Description: Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse. false
          Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to enforce 24 hours/1 day as the minimum password lifetime.

          Add the following line in "/etc/login.defs" (or modify the line to have the required value):

          PASS_MIN_DAYS 1
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:200
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-020190 - OL 8 passwords for new users or password changes must have a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime restriction in "/etc/logins.def".
          Description:Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/etc/login.defs:PASS_MIN_DAYS >= 1)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:20000 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/login.defs:PASS_MIN_DAYS >= 1
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:20000 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*PASS_MIN_DAYS\s+(\d*)'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:20000 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/login.defs'
          • path equals '/etc'
          • filename equals 'login.defs'
          • pattern equals '^\s*PASS_MIN_DAYS\s+(\d*)'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'PASS_MIN_DAYS 0'
          • line equals 'PASS_MIN_DAYS 0'
          • subexpression equals '0'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          subexpression

          V-248696 - OL 8 user account passwords must have a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248696r779654_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020200
          Identities:CCI-000199 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
          Description: Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If OL 8 does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that OL 8 passwords could be compromised. false
          Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime.

          Add or modify the following line in the "/etc/login.defs" file:

          PASS_MAX_DAYS 60
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:201
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-020200 - OL 8 user account passwords must have a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.
          Description:Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If OL 8 does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that OL 8 passwords could be compromised.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (0 -lt /etc/login.defs:PASS_MAX_DAYS -le 60)

          V-248697 - OL 8 user account passwords must be configured so that existing passwords are restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248697r779657_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:OL08-00-020210
          Identities:CCI-000199 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
          Description: Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If OL 8 does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that OL 8 passwords could be compromised. false
          Fix Text:Configure non-compliant accounts to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

          $ sudo chage -M 60 [user]
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Oracle Linux 8
          Identifier:5416
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:202
          Result:false
          Title:OL08-00-020210 - OL 8 user account passwords must be configured so that existing passwords are restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.
          Description:Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If OL 8 does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that OL 8 passwords could be compromised.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (No password in /etc/shadow has a maximum password age of 0 or greater than 60)
            • false (Root password in /etc/shadow does not have a maximum password age of 0 or greater than 60)
            • true (Non-system users do not have a blank entry in /etc/shadow for maximum password age)
            • true (Root does not have a blank entry in /etc/shadow for maximum password age)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:20200 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:No password in /etc/shadow has a maximum password age of 0 or greater than 60
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:20200 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/shadow'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[^:]*:[^:]*:[^:]*:[^:]*:(\d+):'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Exclude Items If:
          • for check = 'all', text, at least one of the following must be true:
            • text matches the pattern '^adm'
            • text matches the pattern '^bin'
            • text matches the pattern '^chrony'
            • text matches the pattern '^daemon'
            • text matches the pattern '^dbus'
            • text matches the pattern '^ftp'
            • text matches the pattern '^games'
            • text matches the pattern '^halt'
            • text matches the pattern '^lp'
            • text matches the pattern '^mail'
            • text matches the pattern '^operator'
            • text matches the pattern '^polkitd'
            • text matches the pattern '^root'
            • text matches the pattern '^shutdown'
            • text matches the pattern '^sshd'
            • text matches the pattern '^sync'
            • text matches the pattern '^systemd-coredump'
            • text matches the pattern '^systemd-resolve'
            • text matches the pattern '^tss'
            • text matches the pattern '^unbound'
            • text matches the pattern '^vboxadd'
          Exclude Items If:
          • text matches the pattern '^nobody'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:20200 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than '0'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:20201 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '60'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/shadow'
          • path equals '/etc'
          • filename equals 'shadow'
          • pattern equals '^[^:]*:[^:]*:[^:]*:[^:]*:(\d+):'
