                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248773 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "init_module" and "finit_module" system calls.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248773r853821_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030360
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                      CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                      CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "init_module" and "finit_module" system calls are used to load a kernel module.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. Performance can be helped, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "init_module" and "finit_module" system calls by adding or updating the following rules in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S init_module,finit_module -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k module_chng
                      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S init_module,finit_module -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k module_chng

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:265
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-030360 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "init_module" and "finit_module" system calls.
                      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "init_module" and "finit_module" system calls are used to load a kernel module.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
                      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of init_module system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of init_module system call.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of finit_module system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of finit_module system call.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:26500 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:Audit 32-bit invocations of init_module system call.
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:26500 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                      • for pattern, the following must be true:
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b32\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-S\s+[,\w]*\binit_module\b[,\w]*\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248774 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "rename", "unlink", "rmdir", "renameat", and "unlinkat" system calls.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248774r853822_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030361
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                      CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                      CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).
                      The "rename" system call will rename the specified files by replacing the first occurrence of expression in their name by replacement.
                      The "unlink" system call deletes a name from the filesystem. If that name was the last link to a file and no processes have the file open, the file is deleted and the space it was using is made available for reuse.
                      The "rmdir" system call removes empty directories.
                      The "renameat" system call renames a file, moving it between directories, if required.
                      The "unlinkat" system call operates in exactly the same way as either "unlink" or "rmdir" except for the differences described in the manual page.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. Performance can be helped, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to generate audit records for any use of the "rename", "unlink", "rmdir", "renameat", and "unlinkat" system calls by adding or updating the following lines to "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

                      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S rename,unlink,rmdir,renameat,unlinkat -F success=1 -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k delete

                      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S rename,unlink,rmdir,renameat,unlinkat -F success=1 -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k delete

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:266
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-030361 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "rename", "unlink", "rmdir", "renameat", and "unlinkat" system calls.
                      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).
                      The "rename" system call will rename the specified files by replacing the first occurrence of expression in their name by replacement.
                      The "unlink" system call deletes a name from the filesystem. If that name was the last link to a file and no processes have the file open, the file is deleted and the space it was using is made available for reuse.
                      The "rmdir" system call removes empty directories.
                      The "renameat" system call renames a file, moving it between directories if required.
                      The "unlinkat" system call operates in exactly the same way as either "unlink" or "rmdir" except for the differences described in the manual page.

                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of rename system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of rename system call.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of unlink system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of unlink system call.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of rmdir system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of rmdir system call.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of renameat system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of renameat system call.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of unlinkat system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of unlinkat system call.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:26600 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:Audit 32-bit invocations of rename system call.
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:26600 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                      • for pattern, the following must be true:
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b32\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-S\s+[,\w]*\brename\b[,\w]*\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-F\s+success=1\s+-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'

                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                      • for pattern, the following must be true:
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b64\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-S\s+[,\w]*\bunlinkat\b[,\w]*\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-F\s+success=1\s+-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248779 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "gpasswd" command.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248779r853823_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030370
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                      CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                      CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "gpasswd" command is used to administer "/etc/group" and "/etc/gshadow". Every group can have administrators, members, and a password.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "gpasswd" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                      -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/gpasswd -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-gpasswd

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:271
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-030370 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "gpasswd" command.
                      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "gpasswd" command is used to administer "/etc/group" and "/etc/gshadow". Every group can have administrators, members, and a password.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215

                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (Audit invocations of /usr/bin/gpasswd.)
                      Tests:

                      Result:false

                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:27100 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                      • for pattern, the following must be true:
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)(?:\s+-S\s+all)?\s+-F\s+path=/usr/bin/gpasswd\s+(?:-F\s+perm=[rwa]*x[rwa]*\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'

                      V-248781 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the delete_module syscall.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248781r853824_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030390
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)

                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)

                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "delete_module" command is used to unload a kernel module.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "delete_module" syscall by adding or updating the following rules in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S delete_module -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k module_chng
                      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S delete_module -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k module_chng

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart

                      V-248782 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "crontab" command.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248782r853825_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030400
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                      CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                      CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "crontab" command is used to maintain crontab files for individual users. Crontab is the program used to install, remove, or list the tables used to drive the cron daemon. This is similar to the task scheduler used in other operating systems.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "crontab" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                      -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/crontab -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-crontab

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).                       V-248783 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "chsh" command.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248783r853826_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030410
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                      CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)

                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chsh" command is used to change the login shell.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "chsh" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                      -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/chsh -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k priv_cmd

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:275
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-030410 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "chsh" command.
                      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chsh" command is used to change the login shell.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (Audit invocations of /usr/bin/chsh.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:27500 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false

                      • for pattern, the following must be true:

                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248784 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "truncate", "ftruncate", "creat", "open", "openat", and "open_by_handle_at" system calls.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248784r853827_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030420
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                      CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                      CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "truncate" and "ftruncate" functions are used to truncate a file to a specified length.
                      The "creat" system call is used to open and possibly create a file or device.
                      The "open" system call opens a file specified by a pathname. If the specified file does not exist, it may optionally be created by "open".
                      The "openat" system call opens a file specified by a relative pathname.
                      The "name_to_handle_at" and "open_by_handle_at" system calls split the functionality of openat into two parts: "name_to_handle_at" returns an opaque handle that corresponds to a specified file; "open_by_handle_at" opens the file corresponding to a handle returned by a previous call to "name_to_handle_at" and returns an open file descriptor.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. Performance can be helped, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "truncate", "ftruncate", "creat", "open", "openat", and "open_by_handle_at" system calls by adding or updating the following rules in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S truncate,ftruncate,creat,open,openat,open_by_handle_at -F exit=-EPERM -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_access
                      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S truncate,ftruncate,creat,open,openat,open_by_handle_at -F exit=-EPERM -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_access

                      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S truncate,ftruncate,creat,open,openat,open_by_handle_at -F exit=-EACCES -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_access
                      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S truncate,ftruncate,creat,open,openat,open_by_handle_at -F exit=-EACCES -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_access

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:276
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-030420 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "truncate", "ftruncate", "creat", "open", "openat", and "open_by_handle_at" system calls.
                      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "truncate" and "ftruncate" functions are used to truncate a file to a specified length.
                      The "creat" system call is used to open and possibly create a file or device.
                      The "open" system call opens a file specified by a pathname. If the specified file does not exist, it may optionally be created by "open".
                      The "openat" system call opens a file specified by a relative pathname.
                      The "name_to_handle_at" and "open_by_handle_at" system calls split the functionality of openat into two parts: "name_to_handle_at" returns an opaque handle that corresponds to a specified file; "open_by_handle_at" opens the file corresponding to a handle returned by a previous call to "name_to_handle_at" and returns an open file descriptor.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
                      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of truncate system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of truncate system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of truncate system with exit EACCES.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of truncate system with exit EACCES.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of ftruncate system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of ftruncate system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of ftruncate system with exit EACCES.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of ftruncate system with exit EACCES.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of creat system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of creat system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of creat system with exit EACCES.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of creat system with exit EACCES.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of open system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of open system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of open system with exit EACCES.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of open system with exit EACCES.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of openat system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of openat system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of openat system with exit EACCES.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of openat system with exit EACCES.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of open_by_handle_at system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of open_by_handle_at system with exit EPERM.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of open_by_handle_at system with exit EACCES.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of open_by_handle_at system with exit EACCES.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:27600 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:Audit 32-bit invocations of truncate system with exit EPERM.
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:27600 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                      • for pattern, the following must be true:
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b32\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-S\s+[,\w]*\btruncate\b[,\w]*\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-F\s+exit=-EPERM\s+-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:27619 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                      • for pattern, the following must be true:
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b64\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-S\s+[,\w]*\bopenat\b[,\w]*\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-F\s+exit=-EACCES\s+-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:27620 (textfilecontent54_test)

                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248790 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "chown", "fchown", "fchownat", and "lchown" system calls.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248790r853828_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030480
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                      CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                      CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).
                      The "chown" command is used to change file owner and group.
                      The "fchown" system call is used to change the ownership of a file referred to by the open file descriptor.
                      The "fchownat" system call is used to change ownership of a file relative to a directory file descriptor.
                      The "lchown" system call is used to change the ownership of the file specified by a path, which does not dereference symbolic links.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. Performance can be helped, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "chown", "fchown", "fchownat", and "lchown" system calls by adding or updating the following line to "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

                      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S chown,fchown,fchownat,lchown -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_chng
                      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S chown,fchown,fchownat,lchown -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_chng

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:282
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-030480 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "chown", "fchown", "fchownat", and "lchown" system calls.
                      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).
                      The "chown" command is used to change file owner and group.
                      The "fchown" system call is used to change the ownership of a file referred to by the open file descriptor.
                      The "fchownat" system call is used to change ownership of a file relative to a directory file descriptor.
                      The "lchown" system call is used to change the ownership of the file specified by a path, which does not dereference symbolic links.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
                      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of chown system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of chown system call.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of fchown system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of fchown system call.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of fchownat system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of fchownat system call.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of lchown system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of lchown system call.)
                      Tests:

                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:28200 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                      • for pattern, the following must be true:
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b32\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-S\s+[,\w]*\bchown\b[,\w]*\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'

                      V-248791 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "chmod", "fchmod", and "fchmodat" system calls.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248791r853829_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030490
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                      CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                      CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chmod" system call changes the file mode bits of each given file according to mode, which can be either a symbolic representation of changes to make or an octal number representing the bit pattern for the new mode bits.
                      The "fchmod" system call is used to change permissions of a file.
                      The "fchmodat" system call is used to change permissions of a file relative to a directory file descriptor.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. Performance can be helped, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "chmod", "fchmod", and "fchmodat" syscalls by adding or updating the following line to "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

                      -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S chmod,fchmod,fchmodat -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_chng
                      -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S chmod,fchmod,fchmodat -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_chng

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:283
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-030490 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "chmod", "fchmod", and "fchmodat" system calls.
                      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).
                      The "chmod" system call changes the file mode bits of each given file according to mode, which can be either a symbolic representation of changes to make or an octal number representing the bit pattern for the new mode bits.
                      The "fchmod" system call is used to change permissions of a file.
                      The "fchmodat" system call is used to change permissions of a file relative to a directory file descriptor.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
                      The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of chmod system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of chmod system call.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of fchmod system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of fchmod system call.)
                        • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of fchmodat system call.)
                        • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of fchmodat system call.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:28300 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:Audit 32-bit invocations of chmod system call.
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:28300 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                      • for pattern, the following must be true:
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b32\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-S\s+[,\w]*\bchmod\b[,\w]*\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:28301 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:Audit 64-bit invocations of chmod system call.
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.

                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b64\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-S\s+[,\w]*\bchmod\b[,\w]*\s+(?:-S\s+[,\w]+\s+)*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'

                      V-248797 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "sudo" command.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248797r853830_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030550
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                      CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                      CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "sudo" command allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser or another user as specified by the security policy.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "sudo" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                      -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/sudo -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k priv_cmd

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:289
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-030550 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "sudo" command.
                      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "sudo" command allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser or another user as specified by the security policy.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (Audit invocations of /usr/bin/sudo.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:28900 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:Audit invocations of /usr/bin/sudo.
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:28900 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                      • for pattern, the following must be true:
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)(?:\s+-S\s+all)?\s+-F\s+path=/usr/bin/sudo\s+(?:-F\s+perm=[rwa]*x[rwa]*\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248798 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "usermod" command.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248798r853831_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030560
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                      CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                      CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "usermod" command modifies the system account files to reflect the changes that are specified on the command line.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "usermod" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                      -a always,exit -F path=/usr/sbin/usermod -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-usermod

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:290
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-030560 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "usermod" command.
                      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "usermod" command modifies the system account files to reflect the changes that are specified on the command line.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (Audit invocations of /usr/sbin/usermod.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:29000 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:Audit invocations of /usr/sbin/usermod.
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:29000 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
                      • for pattern, the following must be true:
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(?:always,exit|exit,always)(?:\s+-S\s+all)?\s+-F\s+path=/usr/sbin/usermod\s+(?:-F\s+perm=[rwa]*x[rwa]*\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)(?:\s+(?:-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248799 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "chacl" command.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248799r853832_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-030570
                      Identities:CCI-000130 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 a)
                      CCI-000135 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3 (1).1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 (1))
                      CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
                      CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
                      CCI-002884 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: MA-4 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: MA-4 (1) (a))
                      Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chacl" command is used to change the access control list of a file or directory.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
                      Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any use of the "chacl" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

                      -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/chacl -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_chng

                      The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the audit daemon, run the following command:

                      $ sudo service auditd restart
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:291
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-030570 - OL 8 must generate audit records for any use of the "chacl" command.
                      Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

                      Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chacl" command is used to change the access control list of a file or directory.

                      When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215

                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
