                      V-248841 - A firewall must be active on OL 8.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248841r853848_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040101
                      Identities:CCI-002314 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-17 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-17 (1))
                      Description: "Firewalld" provides an easy and effective way to block/limit remote access to the system via ports, services, and protocols.

                      Remote access services, such as those providing remote access to network devices and information systems, which lack automated control capabilities, increase risk and make remote user access management difficult at best.

                      Remote access is access to DoD nonpublic information systems by an authorized user (or an information system) communicating through an external, non-organization-controlled network. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.

                      OL 8 functionality (e.g., RDP) must be capable of taking enforcement action if the audit reveals unauthorized activity. Automated control of remote access sessions allows organizations to ensure ongoing compliance with remote access policies by enforcing connection rules of remote access applications on a variety of information system components (e.g., servers, workstations, notebook computers, smartphones, and tablets). false
                      Fix Text:Configure "firewalld" to protect the operating system with the following commands:

                      $ sudo systemctl enable firewalld

                      $ sudo systemctl start firewalld
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:315
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040101 - A firewall must be active on OL 8.
                      Description:"Firewalld" provides an easy and effective way to block/limit remote access to the system via ports, services, and protocols.

                      Remote access services, such as those providing remote access to network devices and information systems, which lack automated control capabilities, increase risk and make remote user access management difficult at best.

                      Remote access is access to DoD nonpublic information systems by an authorized user (or an information system) communicating through an external, non-organization-controlled network. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.

                      OL 8 functionality (e.g., RDP) must be capable of taking enforcement action if the audit reveals unauthorized activity. Automated control of remote access sessions allows organizations to ensure ongoing compliance with remote access policies by enforcing connection rules of remote access applications on a variety of information system components (e.g., servers, workstations, notebook computers, smartphones, and tablets).
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (/usr/sbin/firewalld process is running)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:31500 (process58_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:/usr/sbin/firewalld process is running
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:31500 (process58_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • command_line must match the pattern '/usr/sbin/firewalld\b'
                      • pid must be greater than '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248843 - OL 8 Bluetooth must be disabled.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248843r860921_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040111
                      Identities:CCI-001443 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-18 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AC-18 (1).1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-18 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-18 (1))
                      CCI-001444 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-18 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AC-18 (1).1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-18 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-18 (1))
                      CCI-002418 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SC-8; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SC-8)
                      Description: Without protection of communications with wireless peripherals, confidentiality and integrity may be compromised because unprotected communications can be intercepted and read, altered, or used to compromise the OL 8 operating system.

                      This requirement applies to wireless peripheral technologies (e.g., wireless mice, keyboards, displays, etc.) used with OL 8 systems. Wireless peripherals (e.g., Wi-Fi/Bluetooth/IR keyboards, mice, and pointing devices and Near Field Communications [NFC]) present a unique challenge by creating an open, unsecured port on a computer. Wireless peripherals must meet DoD requirements for wireless data transmission and be approved for use by the Authorizing Official (AO). Although some wireless peripherals, such as mice and pointing devices, do not ordinarily carry information that need to be protected, modification of communications with these wireless peripherals may be used to compromise the OL 8 operating system. Communication paths outside the physical protection of a controlled boundary are exposed to the possibility of interception and modification.

                      Protecting the confidentiality and integrity of communications with wireless peripherals can be accomplished by physical means (e.g., employing physical barriers to wireless radio frequencies) or by logical means (e.g., employing cryptographic techniques). If physical means of protection are employed, logical means (cryptography) do not have to be employed, and vice versa. If the wireless peripheral is only passing telemetry data, encryption of the data may not be required. false
                      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable the Bluetooth adapter when not in use.

                      Build or modify the "/etc/modprobe.d/bluetooth.conf" file with the following line:

                      install bluetooth /bin/true

                      Disable the ability to use the Bluetooth kernel module.

                      $ sudo vi /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf

                      Add or update the line:

                      blacklist bluetooth

                      Reboot the system for the settings to take effect.
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:316
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040111 - OL 8 Bluetooth must be disabled.
                      Description:Without protection of communications with wireless peripherals, confidentiality and integrity may be compromised because unprotected communications can be intercepted and read, altered, or used to compromise the OL 8 operating system.

                      This requirement applies to wireless peripheral technologies (e.g., wireless mice, keyboards, displays, etc.) used with OL 8 systems. Wireless peripherals (e.g., Wi-Fi/Bluetooth/IR keyboards, mice, and pointing devices and Near Field Communications [NFC]) present a unique challenge by creating an open, unsecured port on a computer. Wireless peripherals must meet DoD requirements for wireless data transmission and be approved for use by the Authorizing Official (AO). Although some wireless peripherals, such as mice and pointing devices, do not ordinarily carry information that need to be protected, modification of communications with these wireless peripherals may be used to compromise the OL 8 operating system. Communication paths outside the physical protection of a controlled boundary are exposed to the possibility of interception and modification.

                      Protecting the confidentiality and integrity of communications with wireless peripherals can be accomplished by physical means (e.g., employing physical barriers to wireless radio frequencies) or by logical means (e.g., employing cryptographic techniques). If physical means of protection are employed, logical means (cryptography) do not have to be employed, and vice versa. If the wireless peripheral is only passing telemetry data, encryption of the data may not be required.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (install bluetooth /bin/true is set in /etc/modprobe.d.)
                        • false (blacklist bluetooth is set in /etc/modprobe.d.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:31600 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:install bluetooth /bin/true is set in /etc/modprobe.d.
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:31600 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
                      • filename must match the pattern '.*'
                      • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*install[ \t]+bluetooth[ \t]+/bin/true[ \t]*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:31601 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:blacklist bluetooth is set in /etc/modprobe.d.
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:31601 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
                      • filename must match the pattern '.*'
                      • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*blacklist[ \t]+bluetooth[ \t]*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248846 - OL 8 must mount "/dev/shm" with the "noexec" option.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248846r853855_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040122
                      Identities:CCI-001764 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 (2))
                      Description: The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

                      The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

                      The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

                      The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
                      Fix Text:Configure OL 8 so that "/dev/shm" is mounted with the "noexec" option by adding/modifying "/etc/fstab" with the following line:

                      tmpfs /dev/shm tmpfs defaults,nodev,nosuid,noexec 0 0
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:319
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040122 - OL 8 must mount "/dev/shm" with the "noexec" option.
                      Description:The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

                      The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

                      The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

                      The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (If /dev/shm is mounted, it is mounted with the noexec option)
                        • true (If /dev/shm is configured in /etc/fstab, it is configured with the noexec option)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:31900 (partition_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:If /dev/shm is mounted, it is mounted with the noexec option
                      Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:31700 (partition_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • mount_point must be equal to '/dev/shm'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:31900 (partition_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', mount_options must be equal to 'noexec'
                      Collected Item/State Result:
                      [ false ]
                      • Message - 'device'
                      • mount_point equals '/dev/shm'
                      • device equals 'tmpfs'
                      • uuid does not exist
                      • fs_type equals 'tmpfs'
                      • mount_options equals 'rw'
                      • mount_options equals 'nosuid'
                      • mount_options equals 'nodev'
                      • mount_options equals 'seclabel'
                      • mount_options equals 'inode64'
                      • mount_options equals '6'
                      • total_space equals '249355'
                      • space_used equals '0'
                      • space_left equals '249355'
                      • space_left_for_unprivileged_users equals '249355'
                      • block_size equals '4096'
                      Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
                      mount_options
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:31901 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:true
                      Title:If /dev/shm is configured in /etc/fstab, it is configured with the noexec option
                      Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:31701 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
                      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*[^#\s]+\s+/dev/shm\s+\S+\s+(\S+)\s+\S+\s+\S+\s*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:31901 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '(?:^noexec$|^noexec,|,noexec$|,noexec,)'

                      V-248859 - The OL 8 "fapolicy" module must be installed.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248859r853868_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040135
                      Identities:CCI-001764 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 (2))
                      CCI-001774 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 (5) (b); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 (5) (b))
                      Description: The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

                      Using a whitelist provides a configuration management method for allowing the execution of only authorized software. Using only authorized software decreases risk by limiting the number of potential vulnerabilities. Verification of whitelisted software occurs prior to execution or at system startup.

                      Users' home directories/folders may contain information of a sensitive nature. Non-privileged users should coordinate any sharing of information with a System Administrator through shared resources.

                      OL 8 ships with many optional packages. One such package is a file access policy daemon called "fapolicyd". This is a userspace daemon that determines access rights to files based on attributes of the process and file. It can be used to either blacklist or whitelist processes or file access.

                      Proceed with caution with enforcing the use of this daemon. Improper configuration may render the system non-functional. The "fapolicyd" API is not namespace aware and can cause issues when launching or running containers.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000368-GPOS-00154, SRG-OS-000370-GPOS-00155 false
                      Fix Text:Install "fapolicyd" with the following command:

                      $ sudo yum install fapolicyd.x86_64
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:332
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040135 - The OL 8 "fapolicy" module must be installed.
                      Description:The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

                      Using a whitelist provides a configuration management method for allowing the execution of only authorized software. Using only authorized software decreases risk by limiting the number of potential vulnerabilities. Verification of whitelisted software occurs prior to execution or at system startup.

                      Users' home directories/folders may contain information of a sensitive nature. Non-privileged users should coordinate any sharing of information with a System Administrator through shared resources.

                      OL 8 ships with many optional packages. One such package is a file access policy daemon called "fapolicyd". This is a userspace daemon that determines access rights to files based on attributes of the process and file. It can be used to either blacklist or whitelist processes or file access.

                      Proceed with caution with enforcing the use of this daemon. Improper configuration may render the system non-functional. The "fapolicyd" API is not namespace aware and can cause issues when launching or running containers.

                      Satisfies: SRG-OS-000368-GPOS-00154, SRG-OS-000370-GPOS-00155
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (The fapolicyd package is installed)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:33200 (rpminfo_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:The fapolicyd package is installed
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:33200 (rpminfo_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'fapolicyd'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248862 - OL 8 must have the USBGuard installed.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248862r853871_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040139
                      Identities:CCI-001958 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-3)
                      Description: Without authenticating devices, unidentified or unknown devices may be introduced, thereby facilitating malicious activity.

                      Peripherals include but are not limited to such devices as flash drives, external storage, and printers.

                      A new feature that OL 8 provides is the USBGuard software framework. The USBguard-daemon is the main component of the USBGuard software framework. It runs as a service in the background and enforces the USB device authorization policy for all USB devices. The policy is defined by a set of rules using a rule language described in the "usbguard-rules.conf" file. The policy and the authorization state of USB devices can be modified during runtime using the "usbguard" tool.

                      The System Administrator (SA) must work with the site Information System Security Officer (ISSO) to determine a list of authorized peripherals and establish rules within the USBGuard software framework to allow only authorized devices. false
                      Fix Text:Install the USBGuard package with the following command:

                      $ sudo yum install usbguard.x86_64
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:334
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040139 - OL 8 must have the USBGuard installed.
                      Description:Without authenticating devices, unidentified or unknown devices may be introduced, thereby facilitating malicious activity.

                      Peripherals include but are not limited to such devices as flash drives, external storage, and printers.

                      A new feature that OL 8 provides is the USBGuard software framework. The USBguard-daemon is the main component of the USBGuard software framework. It runs as a service in the background and enforces the USB device authorization policy for all USB devices. The policy is defined by a set of rules using a rule language described in the "usbguard-rules.conf" file. The policy and the authorization state of USB devices can be modified during runtime using the "usbguard" tool.

                      The System Administrator (SA) must work with the site Information System Security Officer (ISSO) to determine a list of authorized peripherals and establish rules within the USBGuard software framework to allow only authorized devices.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (The usbguard package is installed)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:33400 (rpminfo_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:The usbguard package is installed
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:33400 (rpminfo_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'usbguard'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248868 - OL 8 must force a frequent session key renegotiation for SSH connections to the server.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248868r877398_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040161
                      Identities:CCI-000068 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-17 (2); NIST SP 800-53A: AC-17 (2).1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-17 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-17 (2))
                      Description: Unapproved mechanisms that are used for authentication to the cryptographic module are not verified and therefore cannot be relied on to provide confidentiality or integrity, and DoD data may be compromised.

                      Operating systems using encryption are required to use FIPS-compliant mechanisms for authenticating to cryptographic modules.

                      Session key regeneration limits the chances of a session key becoming compromised. false
                      Fix Text:Configure the system to force a frequent session key renegotiation for SSH connections to the server by adding or modifying the following line in the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file:

                      RekeyLimit 1G 1h

                      The SSH daemon must be restarted for the settings to take effect.

                      $ sudo systemctl restart sshd.service
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:336
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040161 - OL 8 must force a frequent session key renegotiation for SSH connections to the server.
                      Description:Unapproved mechanisms that are used for authentication to the cryptographic module are not verified and therefore cannot be relied on to provide confidentiality or integrity, and DoD data may be compromised.

                      Operating systems using encryption are required to use FIPS-compliant mechanisms for authenticating to cryptographic modules.

                      Session key regeneration limits the chances of a session key becoming compromised.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (/etc/ssh/sshd_config:RekeyLimit max data and time are greater than zero.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:33600 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:/etc/ssh/sshd_config:RekeyLimit max data and time are greater than zero.
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:33600 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
                      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*(?i)RekeyLimit\s+(?:\d+[kmg]?)\s+(?:\d+[smdhw]?)+(?-i)\s*'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:33600 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', text must match the pattern '^(?i)\s*RekeyLimit\s+[1-9][0-9]*[kmg]?\s+([1-9][0-9]*[smhdw]?)+\s*$'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248871 - OL 8 must disable the systemd Ctrl-Alt-Delete burst key sequence.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248871r780179_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040172
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: A locally logged-on user who presses Ctrl-Alt-Delete when at the console can reboot the system. If accidentally pressed, as could happen in the case of a mixed OS environment, this can create the risk of short-term loss of availability of systems due to unintentional reboot. In a graphical user environment, risk of unintentional reboot from the Ctrl-Alt-Delete sequence is reduced because the user will be prompted before any action is taken. false
                      Fix Text:Configure the system to disable the CtrlAltDelBurstAction by added or modifying the following line in the "/etc/systemd/system.conf" configuration file:

                      CtrlAltDelBurstAction=none

                      Reload the daemon for this change to take effect:

                      $ sudo systemctl daemon-reload
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:337
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040172 - OL 8 must disable the systemd Ctrl-Alt-Delete burst key sequence.
                      Description:A locally logged-on user who presses Ctrl-Alt-Delete when at the console can reboot the system. If accidentally pressed, as could happen in the case of a mixed OS environment, this can create the risk of short-term loss of availability of systems due to unintentional reboot. In a graphical user environment, risk of unintentional reboot from the Ctrl-Alt-Delete sequence is reduced because the user will be prompted before any action is taken.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (CtrlAltDelBurstAction is set to none in /etc/systemd/system.conf.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:33700 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:CtrlAltDelBurstAction is set to none in /etc/systemd/system.conf.
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:33700 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/systemd/system.conf'
                      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*CtrlAltDelBurstAction\s*=\s*(\S+)\s*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:33700 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'none'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248875 - OL 8 must prevent IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages from being accepted.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248875r858651_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040209
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.

                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf false
                      Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to prevent IPv4 ICMP redirect messages from being accepted with the following command:

                      $ sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects=0

                      Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

                      If "0" is not the system's default value then add or update the following line in the appropriate file under "/etc/sysctl.d":

                      net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects=0
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:340
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040209 - OL 8 must prevent IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages from being accepted.
                      Description:ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0)
                        • false (net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in a configuration file in an acceptable directory is set to 0, and nothing else, and no conflicting configurations are in the files)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:34000 (sysctl_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:34000 (sysctl_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:34000 (sysctl_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '0'
                      Collected Item/State Result:
                      [ false ]
                      • name equals 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects'
                      • value equals '1'
                      Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
                      value
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:34001 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in a configuration file in an acceptable directory is set to 0, and nothing else, and no conflicting configurations are in the files
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:34003 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • Collect any available items.
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:34001 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248876 - OL 8 must prevent IPv6 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages from being accepted.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248876r858653_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040210
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.

                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom.                       /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf false

                      $ sudo sysctl -w net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_redirects=0

                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

                      If "0" is not the system's default value, add or update the following line in "/etc/sysctl.conf" or in the appropriate file under "/etc/sysctl.d":

                      net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_redirects=0

                      V-248877 - OL 8 must not send Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248877r858655_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040220
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages contain information from the system's route table, possibly revealing portions of the network topology.

                      There are notable differences between Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) and Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6). There is only a directive to disable sending of IPv4 redirected packets. Refer to RFC4294 for an explanation of "IPv6 Node Requirements", which resulted in this difference between IPv4 and IPv6.

                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf false
                      Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to not allow interfaces to perform IPv4 ICMP redirects with the following command:

                      $ sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects=0

                      Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

                      If "0" is not the system's default value, add or update the following line in "/etc/sysctl.conf" or in the appropriate file under "/etc/sysctl.d":

                      net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects=0
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:342
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040220 - OL 8 must not send Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects.
                      Description:ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages contain information from the system's route table, possibly revealing portions of the network topology.

                      There are notable differences between Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) and Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6). There is only a directive to disable sending of IPv4 redirected packets. Refer to RFC4294 for an explanation of "IPv6 Node Requirements", which resulted in this difference between IPv4 and IPv6.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0)
                        • false (net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects setting in acceptable directory is set to 0, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:34200 (sysctl_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:34200 (sysctl_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:34200 (sysctl_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '0'
                      Collected Item/State Result:
                      [ false ]
                      • name equals 'net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects'
                      • value equals '1'
                      Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
                      value
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:34201 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects setting in acceptable directory is set to 0, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:34203 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • Collect any available items.
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:34201 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248878 - OL 8 must not respond to Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echoes sent to a broadcast address.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248878r858657_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040230
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: Responding to broadcast ICMP echoes facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.

                      There are notable differences between Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) and Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6). IPv6 does not implement the same method of broadcast as IPv4. Instead, IPv6 uses multicast addressing to the all-hosts multicast group. Refer to RFC4294 for an explanation of "IPv6 Node Requirements", which resulted in this difference between IPv4 and IPv6.

                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf false
                      Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to not respond to IPv4 ICMP echoes sent to a broadcast address with the following command:

                      $ sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1

                      Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

                      If "1" is not the system's default value, add or update the following line in "/etc/sysctl.conf" or in the appropriate file under "/etc/sysctl.d":

                      net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:343
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040230 - OL 8 must not respond to Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echoes sent to a broadcast address.
                      Description:Responding to broadcast ICMP echoes facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.

                      There are notable differences between Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) and Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6). IPv6 does not implement the same method of broadcast as IPv4. Instead, IPv6 uses multicast addressing to the all-hosts multicast group. Refer to RFC4294 for an explanation of "IPv6 Node Requirements", which resulted in this difference between IPv4 and IPv6.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • true (net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts setting in kernel is set to 1)
                        • false (net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts setting in acceptable directory is set to 1, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:34300 (sysctl_test)
                      Result:true
                      Title:net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts setting in kernel is set to 1
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:34300 (sysctl_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:34300 (sysctl_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '1'
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:34301 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts setting in acceptable directory is set to 1, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:34303 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • Collect any available items.
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:34301 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248880 - OL 8 must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248880r858661_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040240
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.

                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf false
                      Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to not forward IPv6 source-routed packets with the following command:

                      $ sudo sysctl -w net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route=0

                      Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

                      If "0" is not the system's all value then add or update the following line in the appropriate file under "/etc/sysctl.d":

                      net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route=0
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:345
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040240 - OL 8 must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets.
                      Description:Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.
                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                        • false (All child checks must be true.)
                          • true (net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route setting in kernel is set to 0)
                          • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route is set to 0, and nothing else)
                        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                          • false (All child checks must be true.)
                            • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in kernel is set to 1)
                            • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else)
                          • false (ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:34500 (sysctl_test)
                      Result:true
                      Title:net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route setting in kernel is set to 0
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:34500 (sysctl_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:34500 (sysctl_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '0'
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:34501 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route is set to 0, and nothing else
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:34503 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • Collect any available items.
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:34501 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:1400 (sysctl_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in kernel is set to 1
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:1400 (sysctl_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:1400 (sysctl_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '1'
                      Collected Item/State Result:
                      [ false ]
                      • name equals 'net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6'
                      • value equals '0'
                      Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
                      value
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:1401 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:1403 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • Collect any available items.
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:1401 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:1402 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:1404 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/proc/cmdline'
                      • pattern must match the pattern '\bipv6\.disable=1\b'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248881 - OL 8 must not forward IPv4 source-routed packets by default.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248881r858663_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040249
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.

                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf false
                      Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to not forward IPv4 source-routed packets by default with the following command:

                      $ sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route=0

                      Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

                      If "0" is not the system's default value then add or update the following line in the appropriate file under "/etc/sysctl.d":

                      net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route=0
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:346
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040249 - OL 8 must not forward IPv4 source-routed packets by default.
                      Description:Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route setting in kernel is set to 0)
                        • false (net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route setting in acceptable directory is set to 0, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files)

                      • name must be equal to 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:34600 (sysctl_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '0'
                      Collected Item/State Result:
                      [ false ]
                      • name equals 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route'
                      • value equals '1'
                      Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
                      value
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:34601 (textfilecontent54_test)

                      V-248882 - OL 8 must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets by default.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248882r858665_rule

                      Version:OL08-00-040250

                      Description: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.

                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files.                       /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf

                      V-248883 - OL 8 must not enable IPv6 packet forwarding unless the system is a router.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248883r858669_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040260
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.

                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf false
                      Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to not allow IPv6 packet forwarding unless the system is a router with the following command:

                      $ sudo sysctl -w net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding=0

                      Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

                      If "0" is not the system's default value, add or update the following lines in "/etc/sysctl.conf" or in the appropriate file under "/etc/sysctl.d":

                      net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding=0
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:348
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040260 - OL 8 must not enable IPv6 packet forwarding unless the system is a router.
                      Description:Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.
                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                        • false (All child checks must be true.)
                          • true (net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding setting in kernel is set to 0)
                          • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding setting in /etc/sysctl.d/99-sysctl.conf is set to 0, and nothing else)
                        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                          • false (All child checks must be true.)
                            • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in kernel is set to 1)
                            • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else)
                          • false (ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:34800 (sysctl_test)
                      Result:true
                      Title:net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding setting in kernel is set to 0
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:34800 (sysctl_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:34800 (sysctl_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '0'
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:34801 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding setting in /etc/sysctl.d/99-sysctl.conf is set to 0, and nothing else
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:34803 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • Collect any available items.
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:34801 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:1400 (sysctl_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in kernel is set to 1
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:1400 (sysctl_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:1400 (sysctl_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '1'

                      [ false ]
                      • name equals 'net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6'
                      • value equals '0'

                      value
