                      V-248894 - OL 8 must enable hardening for the Berkeley Packet Filter Just-in-time compiler.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248894r858691_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040286
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

                      Enabling hardening for the Berkeley Packet Filter (BPF) Just-in-time (JIT) compiler aids in mitigating JIT spraying attacks. Setting the value to "2" enables JIT hardening for all users.

                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf false
                      Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to enable hardening for the BPF JIT compiler by adding the following line to a file in the "/etc/sysctl.d" directory:

                      net.core.bpf_jit_harden = 2

                      Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

                      The system configuration files need to be reloaded for the changes to take effect. To reload the contents of the files, run the following command:

                      $ sudo sysctl --system
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:359
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040286 - OL 8 must enable hardening for the Berkeley Packet Filter Just-in-time compiler.
                      Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

                      Enabling hardening for the Berkeley Packet Filter (BPF) Just-in-time (JIT) compiler aids in mitigating JIT spraying attacks. Setting the value to "2" enables JIT hardening for all users.
                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (net.core.bpf_jit_harden setting in kernel is set to 2)
                        • false (net.core.bpf_jit_harden setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 2, and nothing else)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:35900 (sysctl_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.core.bpf_jit_harden setting in kernel is set to 2
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:35900 (sysctl_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'net.core.bpf_jit_harden'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:35900 (sysctl_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '2'
                      Collected Item/State Result:
                      [ false ]
                      • name equals 'net.core.bpf_jit_harden'
                      • value equals '0'
                      Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
                      value
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:35901 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:net.core.bpf_jit_harden setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 2, and nothing else
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:35903 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • Collect any available items.
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:35901 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '2'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248900 - OL 8 remote X connections for interactive users must be disabled unless to fulfill documented and validated mission requirements.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248900r858588_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040340
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: The security risk of using X11 forwarding is that the client's X11 display server may be exposed to attack when the SSH client requests forwarding. A System Administrator may have a stance in which they want to protect clients that may expose themselves to attack by unwittingly requesting X11 forwarding, which can warrant a "no" setting.

                      X11 forwarding should be enabled with caution. Users with the ability to bypass file permissions on the remote host (for the user's X11 authorization database) can access the local X11 display through the forwarded connection. An attacker may then be able to perform activities such as keystroke monitoring if the "ForwardX11Trusted" option is also enabled.

                      If X11 services are not required for the system's intended function, they should be disabled or restricted as appropriate to the systems needs. false
                      Fix Text:Edit the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file to uncomment or add the line for the "X11Forwarding" keyword and set its value to "no" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor):

                      X11Forwarding no

                      The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect:

                      $ sudo systemctl restart sshd
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:361
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040340 - OL 8 remote X connections for interactive users must be disabled unless to fulfill documented and validated mission requirements.
                      Description:The security risk of using X11 forwarding is that the client's X11 display server may be exposed to attack when the SSH client requests forwarding. A System Administrator may have a stance in which they want to protect clients that may expose themselves to attack by unwittingly requesting X11 forwarding, which can warrant a "no" setting.

                      X11 forwarding should be enabled with caution. Users with the ability to bypass file permissions on the remote host (for the user's X11 authorization database) can access the local X11 display through the forwarded connection. An attacker may then be able to perform activities such as keystroke monitoring if the "ForwardX11Trusted" option is also enabled.

                      If X11 services are not required for the system's intended function, they should be disabled or restricted as appropriate to the system's needs.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (Query the value of the X11Forwarding setting in /etc/ssh/sshd_config)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:36100 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:Query the value of the X11Forwarding setting in /etc/ssh/sshd_config
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:36100 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • behavior requirements:
                        • ignore_case = true
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
                      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*X11Forwarding[ \t]+([^\s#]*)[ \t]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:36100 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^(no|"no")$'
                      Collected Item/State Result:
                      [ false ]
                      • filepath equals '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
                      • path equals '/etc/ssh'
                      • filename equals 'sshd_config'
                      • pattern equals '^\s*X11Forwarding[ \t]+([^\s#]*)[ \t]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
                      • instance equals '1'
                      • text equals 'X11Forwarding yes'
                      • line equals 'X11Forwarding yes'
                      • subexpression equals 'yes'
                      Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
                      subexpression

                      V-248901 - The OL 8 SSH daemon must prevent remote hosts from connecting to the proxy display.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248901r858590_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-040341
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: When X11 forwarding is enabled, there may be additional exposure to the server and client displays if the sshd proxy display is configured to listen on the wildcard address. By default, sshd binds the forwarding server to the loopback address and sets the hostname part of the DISPLAY environment variable to localhost. This prevents remote hosts from connecting to the proxy display. false
                      Fix Text:Configure the OL 8 SSH daemon to prevent remote hosts from connecting to the proxy display.

                      Edit the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file to uncomment or add the line for the "X11UseLocalhost" keyword and set its value to "yes" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor):

                      X11UseLocalhost yes
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:362
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-040341 - The OL 8 SSH daemon must prevent remote hosts from connecting to the proxy display.
                      Description:When X11 forwarding is enabled, there may be additional exposure to the server and client displays if the sshd proxy display is configured to listen on the wildcard address. By default, sshd binds the forwarding server to the loopback address and sets the hostname part of the DISPLAY environment variable to localhost. This prevents remote hosts from connecting to the proxy display.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (sshd_config X11UseLocalhost is set to 2.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:36200 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:sshd_config X11UseLocalhost is set to 2.
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:36200 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
                      • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*(?i)X11UseLocalhost(?-i)\s+"?(\S+?)"?\s*(?:#.*|$)'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:36200 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'yes'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-252658 - OL 8 systems below version 8.4 must ensure the password complexity module in the system-auth file is configured for three retries or less.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-252658r902815_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-020102
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. "pwquality" enforces complex password construction configuration and has the ability to limit brute-force attacks on the system.

                      OL 8 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. This is set in both:
                      /etc/pam.d/password-auth
                      /etc/pam.d/system-auth
                      By limiting the number of attempts to meet the pwquality module complexity requirements before returning with an error, the system will audit abnormal attempts at password changes. false
                      Fix Text:Configure the operating system to limit the "pwquality" retry option to 3.

                      Add the following line to the "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" file (or modify the line to have the required value):

                      password requisite pam_pwquality.so retry=3
                      Severity:medium
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8os:def:252658
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-020102 - OL 8 systems below version 8.4 must ensure the password complexity module in the system-auth file is configured for three retries or less.
                      Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. "pwquality" enforces complex password construction configuration and has the ability to limit brute-force attacks on the system.

                      OL 8 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. This is set in both:
                      /etc/pam.d/password-auth
                      /etc/pam.d/system-auth
                      By limiting the number of attempts to meet the pwquality module complexity requirements before returning with an error, the system will audit abnormal attempts at password changes.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (All child checks must be true.)
                          • false (/etc/pam.d/system-auth:retry not greater than 3 and not 0)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:25171400 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:/etc/pam.d/system-auth:retry not greater than 3 and not 0
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:25171400 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
                      • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*password[ \t]+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))[ \t]+pam_pwquality\.so(?:[ \t]+|(?:[ \t][^#\r\f\n]+[ \t]+))retry=([0-9]+)(?:\s|$)'
                      • instance must be equal to '1'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:ste:20000018 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[123]$'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                    Detailed Results: Low Severity (CAT III)

                      V-248563 - The OL 8 SSH server must be configured to use strong entropy.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248563r779255_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-010292
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: The most important characteristic of a random number generator is its randomness, namely its ability to deliver random numbers that are impossible to predict. Entropy in computer security is associated with the unpredictability of a source of randomness. The random source with high entropy tends to achieve a uniform distribution of random values. Random number generators are one of the most important building blocks of cryptosystems.

                      The SSH implementation in OL 8 uses the OPENSSL library, which does not use high-entropy sources by default. By using the SSH_USE_STRONG_RNG environment variable, the OPENSSL random generator is reseeded from "/dev/random". This setting is not recommended on computers without the hardware random generator because insufficient entropy causes the connection to be blocked until enough entropy is available. false
                      Fix Text:Configure the operating system SSH server to use strong entropy.

                      Add or modify the following line in the "/etc/sysconfig/sshd" file.

                      SSH_USE_STRONG_RNG=32

                      The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.
                      Severity:low
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:127
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-010292 - The OL 8 SSH server must be configured to use strong entropy.
                      Description:The most important characteristic of a random number generator is its randomness, namely its ability to deliver random numbers that are impossible to predict. Entropy in computer security is associated with the unpredictability of a source of randomness. The random source with high entropy tends to achieve a uniform distribution of random values. Random number generators are one of the most important building blocks of cryptosystems.

                      The SSH implementation in OL 8 uses the OPENSSL library, which does not use high-entropy sources by default. By using the SSH_USE_STRONG_RNG environment variable, the OPENSSL random generator is reseeded from "/dev/random". This setting is not recommended on computers without the hardware random generator because insufficient entropy causes the connection to be blocked until enough entropy is available.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (/etc/sysconfig/sshd: SSH_USE_STRONG_RNG=32)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:12700 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:/etc/sysconfig/sshd: SSH_USE_STRONG_RNG=32
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:12700 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/sysconfig/sshd'
                      • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*SSH_USE_STRONG_RNG[ \t]*=[ \t]*(\d+)[ \t]*$'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:12700 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '32'
                      Collected Item/State Result:
                      [ false ]
                      • filepath equals '/etc/sysconfig/sshd'
                      • path equals '/etc/sysconfig'
                      • filename equals 'sshd'
                      • pattern equals '^[ \t]*SSH_USE_STRONG_RNG[ \t]*=[ \t]*(\d+)[ \t]*$'
                      • instance equals '1'
                      • text equals 'SSH_USE_STRONG_RNG=0'
                      • line equals 'SSH_USE_STRONG_RNG=0'
                      • subexpression equals '0'
                      Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
                      subexpression

                      V-248579 - OL 8 must restrict access to the kernel message buffer.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248579r858617_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-010375
                      Identities:CCI-001090 (NIST SP 800-53: SC-4; NIST SP 800-53A: SC-4.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SC-4; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SC-4)
                      Description: Preventing unauthorized information transfers mitigates the risk of information, including encrypted representations of information, produced by the actions of prior users/roles (or the actions of processes acting on behalf of prior users/roles) from being available to any current users/roles (or current processes) that obtain access to shared system resources (e.g., registers, main memory, hard disks) after those resources have been released back to information systems. The control of information in shared resources is also commonly referred to as object reuse and residual information protection.

                      This requirement generally applies to the design of an information technology product, but it can also apply to the configuration of particular information system components that are, or use, such products. This can be verified by acceptance/validation processes in DoD or other government agencies.

                      There may be shared resources with configurable protections (e.g., files in storage) that may be assessed on specific information system components.

                      Restricting access to the kernel message buffer limits access to only root. This prevents attackers from gaining additional system information as a non-privileged user.

                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf false
                      Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to restrict access to the kernel message buffer.

                      Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

                      kernel.dmesg_restrict = 1

                      Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

                      Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

                      $ sudo sysctl --system
                      Severity:low
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:137
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-010375 - OL 8 must restrict access to the kernel message buffer.
                      Description:Preventing unauthorized information transfers mitigates the risk of information, including encrypted representations of information, produced by the actions of prior users/roles (or the actions of processes acting on behalf of prior users/roles) from being available to any current users/roles (or current processes) that obtain access to shared system resources (e.g., registers, main memory, hard disks) after those resources have been released back to information systems. The control of information in shared resources is also commonly referred to as object reuse and residual information protection.

                      This requirement generally applies to the design of an information technology product, but it can also apply to the configuration of particular information system components that are, or use, such products. This can be verified by acceptance/validation processes in DoD or other government agencies.

                      There may be shared resources with configurable protections (e.g., files in storage) that may be assessed on specific information system components.

                      Restricting access to the kernel message buffer limits access to only root. This prevents attackers from gaining additional system information as a non-privileged user.
                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (kernel.dmesg_restrict setting in kernel is set to 1)
                        • false (kernel.dmesg_restrict setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:13700 (sysctl_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:kernel.dmesg_restrict setting in kernel is set to 1
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:13700 (sysctl_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'kernel.dmesg_restrict'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:13700 (sysctl_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '1'
                      Collected Item/State Result:
                      [ false ]
                      • name equals 'kernel.dmesg_restrict'
                      • value equals '0'
                      Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
                      value
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:13701 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:kernel.dmesg_restrict setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:13703 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • Collect any available items.
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:13701 (textfilecontent54_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248580 - OL 8 must prevent kernel profiling by unprivileged users.

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248580r858619_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-010376
                      Identities:CCI-001090 (NIST SP 800-53: SC-4; NIST SP 800-53A: SC-4.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SC-4; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SC-4)
                      Description: Preventing unauthorized information transfers mitigates the risk of information, including encrypted representations of information, produced by the actions of prior users/roles (or the actions of processes acting on behalf of prior users/roles) from being available to any current users/roles (or current processes) that obtain access to shared system resources (e.g., registers, main memory, hard disks) after those resources have been released back to information systems. The control of information in shared resources is also commonly referred to as object reuse and residual information protection.

                      This requirement generally applies to the design of an information technology product, but it can also apply to the configuration of particular information system components that are, or use, such products. This can be verified by acceptance/validation processes in DoD or other government agencies.

                      There may be shared resources with configurable protections (e.g., files in storage) that may be assessed on specific information system components.

                      Setting the "kernel.perf_event_paranoid" kernel parameter to "2" prevents attackers from gaining additional system information as a non-privileged user.

                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf false
                      Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to prevent kernel profiling by unprivileged users.

                      Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

                      kernel.perf_event_paranoid = 2

                      Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

                      Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

                      $ sudo sysctl --system
                      Severity:low
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:138
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-010376 - OL 8 must prevent kernel profiling by unprivileged users.
                      Description:Preventing unauthorized information transfers mitigates the risk of information, including encrypted representations of information, produced by the actions of prior users/roles (or the actions of processes acting on behalf of prior users/roles) from being available to any current users/roles (or current processes) that obtain access to shared system resources (e.g., registers, main memory, hard disks) after those resources have been released back to information systems. The control of information in shared resources is also commonly referred to as object reuse and residual information protection.

                      This requirement generally applies to the design of an information technology product, but it can also apply to the configuration of particular information system components that are, or use, such products. This can be verified by acceptance/validation processes in DoD or other government agencies.

                      There may be shared resources with configurable protections (e.g., files in storage) that may be assessed on specific information system components.

                      Setting the "kernel.perf_event_paranoid" kernel parameter to "2" prevents attackers from gaining additional system information as a non-privileged user.
                      The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
                      /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
                      /etc/sysctl.conf
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • true (kernel.perf_event_paranoid setting in kernel is set to 2)
                        • false (kernel.perf_event_paranoid setting in /etc/sysctl.d/99-*.conf is set to 2, and nothing else)

                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:13800 (sysctl_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • name must be equal to 'kernel.perf_event_paranoid'
                      State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:13800 (sysctl_state)
                      State Requirements:
                      • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '2'
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:13801 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:kernel.perf_event_paranoid setting in /etc/sysctl.d/99-*.conf is set to 2, and nothing else
                      Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                      Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:13803 (textfilecontent54_object)

                      V-248608 - OL 8 must use a separate file system for "/var".

                      Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248608r902793_rule
                      Test Type:Automated
                      Result:Fail
                      Version:OL08-00-010540
                      Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
                      Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
                      Fix Text:Migrate the "/var" path onto a separate file system.
                      Severity:low
                      Weight:10.0
                      Reference:
                      Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                      Publisher:DISA
                      Type:DPMS Target
                      Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                      Identifier:5416
                      Definitions:
                      Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8os:def:248608
                      Result:false
                      Title:OL08-00-010540 - OL 8 must use a separate file system for "/var".
                      Description:The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.
                      Class:compliance
                      Tests:
                      • false (All child checks must be true.)
                        • false (All child checks must be true.)
                          • false (There is a separate file system for /var.)
                          • false (There is a separate file system configured for /var.)
                      Tests:
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.linux:tst:23029200 (partition_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:There is a separate file system for /var.
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.linux:obj:23029200 (partition_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • mount_point must be equal to '/var'
                      Collected Item/State Result:
                      [ not evaluated ]
                      • mount_point does not exist
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
                      Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23029201 (textfilecontent54_test)
                      Result:false
                      Title:There is a separate file system configured for /var.
                      Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
                      Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                      Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23029201 (textfilecontent54_object)
                      Object Requirements:
                      • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
                      • pattern must match the pattern '^[^# \t]+\s+/var\s+'
                      • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                      Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                      V-248609 - OL 8 must use a separate file system for "/var/log".

                        V-248666 - OL 8 must limit the number of concurrent sessions to 10 for all accounts and/or account types.

                        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248666r877399_rule
                        Test Type:Automated
                        Result:Fail
                        Version:OL08-00-020024
                        Identities:CCI-000054 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-10; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-10.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-10; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-10)
                        Description: Operating system management includes the ability to control the number of users and user sessions that use an operating system. Limiting the number of allowed users and sessions per user is helpful in reducing the risks related to denial-of-service attacks.

                        This requirement addresses concurrent sessions for information system accounts and does not address concurrent sessions by single users via multiple system accounts. The maximum number of concurrent sessions should be defined based on mission needs and the operational environment for each system. false
                        Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to limit the number of concurrent sessions to 10 for all accounts and/or account types.

                        Add the following line to the top of "/etc/security/limits.conf" or in a ".conf" file defined in "/etc/security/limits.d/":

                        * hard maxlogins 10
                        Severity:low
                        Weight:10.0
                        Reference:
                        Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                        Publisher:DISA
                        Type:DPMS Target
                        Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                        Identifier:5416
                        Definitions:
                        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8os:def:248666
                        Result:false
                        Title:OL08-00-020024 - OL 8 must limit the number of concurrent sessions to 10 for all accounts and/or account types.
                        Description:Operating system management includes the ability to control the number of users and user sessions that use an operating system. Limiting the number of allowed users and sessions per user is helpful in reducing the risks related to denial-of-service attacks.

                        This requirement addresses concurrent sessions for information system accounts and does not address concurrent sessions by single users via multiple system accounts. The maximum number of concurrent sessions should be defined based on mission needs and the operational environment for each system.
                        Class:compliance
                        Tests:
                        • false (All child checks must be true.)
                          • false (All child checks must be true.)
                            • false (limits.conf and limits.d/*.conf:maxlogins is set to 10 or less by default)
                            • true (limits.conf and limits.d/*.conf:maxlogins is set to 10 or less for non-default domains)
                        Tests:
                        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23034600 (textfilecontent54_test)
                        Result:false
                        Title:limits.conf and limits.d/*.conf:maxlogins is set to 10 or less by default
                        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23034600 (textfilecontent54_object)
                        Object Requirements:
                        • Collect any available items.
                        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:ste:23034600 (textfilecontent54_state)
                        State Requirements:
                        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '10'
                        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
                        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23034601 (textfilecontent54_test)
                        Result:true
                        Title:limits.conf and limits.d/*.conf:maxlogins is set to 10 or less for non-default domains
                        Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
                        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23034603 (textfilecontent54_object)
                        Object Requirements:
                        • Collect any available items.
                        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:ste:23034600 (textfilecontent54_state)
                        State Requirements:
                        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '10'

                        V-248687 - OL 8 must enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one uppercase character be used.

                        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248687r858631_rule
                        Test Type:Automated
                        Result:Fail
                        Version:OL08-00-020110
                        Identities:CCI-000192 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
                        CCI-000193 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
                        Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

                        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

                        OL 8 uses pwquality as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Note that in order to require uppercase characters without degrading the "minlen" value, the credit value must be expressed as a negative number in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf".

                        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000069-GPOS-00037, SRG-OS-000070-GPOS-00038 false
                        Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one uppercase character be used by setting the "ucredit" option.

                        Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory:

                        ucredit = -1

                        Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.
                        Severity:low
                        Weight:10.0
                        Reference:
                        Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                        Publisher:DISA
                        Type:DPMS Target
                        Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                        Identifier:5416
                        Definitions:
                        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:192
                        Result:false
                        Title:OL08-00-020110 - OL 8 must enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one uppercase character be used.
                        Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

                        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

                        OL 8 uses pwquality as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Note that in order to require uppercase characters without degrading the "minlen" value, the credit value must be expressed as a negative number in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf".
                        Class:compliance
                        Tests:
                        • false (All child checks must be true.)
                          • false (at least one uppercase character is required)
                        Tests:
                        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:19200 (textfilecontent54_test)
                        Result:false
                        Title:at least one uppercase character is required
                        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:19202 (textfilecontent54_object)
                        Object Requirements:
                        • Collect any available items.
                        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:19200 (textfilecontent54_state)
                        State Requirements:
                        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than '0'
                        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                        V-248688 - OL 8 must enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one lowercase character be used.

                        Result:Fail

                        Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

                        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

                        OL 8 uses pwquality as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Note that in order to require lowercase characters without degrading the "minlen" value, the credit value must be expressed as a negative number in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf". false

                        Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory:

                        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

                        OL 8 uses pwquality as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Note that in order to require lowercase characters without degrading the "minlen" value, the credit value must be expressed as a negative number in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf".

                        V-248693 - OL 8 must require the change of at least 8 characters when passwords are changed.

                        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248693r858643_rule
                        Test Type:Automated
                        Result:Fail
                        Version:OL08-00-020170
                        Identities:CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
                        Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

                        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

                        OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "difok" option sets the number of characters in a password that must not be present in the old password. false
                        Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to require the change of at least eight of the total number of characters when passwords are changed by setting the "difok" option.

                        Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory:

                        difok = 8

                        Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.
                        Severity:low
                        Weight:10.0
                        Reference:
                        Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                        Publisher:DISA
                        Type:DPMS Target
                        Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                        Identifier:5416
                        Definitions:
                        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:198
                        Result:false
                        Title:OL08-00-020170 - OL 8 must require the change of at least 8 characters when passwords are changed.
                        Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

                        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

                        OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "difok" option sets the number of characters in a password that must not be present in the old password.
                        Class:compliance
                        Tests:
                        • false (All child checks must be true.)
                          • false (at least 8 characters must change when passwords are changed)
                        Tests:
                        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:19800 (textfilecontent54_test)
                        Result:false
                        Title:at least 8 characters must change when passwords are changed
                        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:19802 (textfilecontent54_object)
                        Object Requirements:
                        • Collect any available items.
                        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:19800 (textfilecontent54_state)
                        State Requirements:
                        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '8'
                        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                        V-248698 - OL 8 must be configured in the password-auth file to prohibit password reuse for a minimum of five generations.

                        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248698r902821_rule
                        Test Type:Automated
                        Result:Fail
                        Version:OL08-00-020220
                        Identities:CCI-000200 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (e); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (e))
                        Description: Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. If the information system or application allows the user to reuse their password consecutively when that password has exceeded its defined lifetime, the end result is a password that is not changed per policy requirements.

                        OL 8 uses "pwhistory" consecutively as a mechanism to prohibit password reuse. This is set in both of the following:
                        /etc/pam.d/password-auth
                        /etc/pam.d/system-auth

                        Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program. false
                        Fix Text:Configure the operating system in the password-auth file to prohibit password reuse for a minimum of five generations.

                        Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" (or modify the line to have the required value):

                        password requisite pam_pwhistory.so use_authtok remember=5 retry=3
                        Severity:low
                        Weight:10.0
                        Reference:
                        Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                        Publisher:DISA
                        Type:DPMS Target
                        Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                        Identifier:5416
                        Definitions:
                        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8os:def:248698
                        Result:false
                        Title:OL08-00-020220 - OL 8 must be configured in the password-auth file to prohibit password reuse for a minimum of five generations.
                        Description:Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. If the information system or application allows the user to reuse their password consecutively when that password has exceeded its defined lifetime, the end result is a password that is not changed per policy requirements.

                        OL 8 uses "pwhistory" consecutively as a mechanism to prohibit password reuse. This is set in both of the following:
                        /etc/pam.d/password-auth
                        /etc/pam.d/system-auth

                        Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.
                        Class:compliance
                        Tests:
                        • false (All child checks must be true.)
                          • false (All child checks must be true.)
                            • false (/etc/pam.d/password-auth: pam_pwhistory.so has remember set to 5 or greater)
                        Tests:
                        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23036800 (textfilecontent54_test)
                        Result:false
                        Title:/etc/pam.d/password-auth: pam_pwhistory.so has remember set to 5 or greater
                        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23036800 (textfilecontent54_object)
                        Object Requirements:
                        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/password-auth'
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:required|requisite)\s+pam_pwhistory\.so\s+[^#\n]*\bremember=(\d+)\b'
                        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:ste:23036800 (textfilecontent54_state)
                        State Requirements:
                        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '5'
                        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                        V-248709 - All OL 8 passwords must contain at least one special character.

                        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248709r858647_rule
                        Test Type:Automated
                        Result:Fail
                        Version:OL08-00-020280
                        Identities:CCI-001619 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
                        Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

                        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

                        OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Note that to require special characters without degrading the "minlen" value, the credit value must be expressed as a negative number in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf". false
                        Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one special character be used by setting the "ocredit" option.

                        Add or update the following line in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" file or a configuration file in the "/etc/security/pwquality.conf.d/" directory:

                        ocredit = -1

                        Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.
                        Severity:low
                        Weight:10.0
                        Reference:
                        Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                        Publisher:DISA
                        Type:DPMS Target
                        Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                        Identifier:5416
                        Definitions:
                        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:210
                        Result:false
                        Title:OL08-00-020280 - All OL 8 passwords must contain at least one special character.
                        Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

                        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

                        OL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Note that to require special characters without degrading the "minlen" value, the credit value must be expressed as a negative number in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf".
                        Class:compliance
                        Tests:
                        • false (All child checks must be true.)
                          • false (passwords must contain at least one special character)
                        Tests:
                        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:21000 (textfilecontent54_test)
                        Result:false
                        Title:passwords must contain at least one special character
                        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
                        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:21002 (textfilecontent54_object)
                        Object Requirements:
                        • Collect any available items.
                        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:ste:21000 (textfilecontent54_state)
                        State Requirements:
                        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than '0'
                        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

                        V-248821 - OL 8 must disable the chrony daemon from acting as a server.

                        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-248821r780029_rule
                        Test Type:Automated
                        Result:Fail
                        Version:OL08-00-030741
                        Identities:CCI-000381 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-7; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 a)
                        Description: Inaccurate time stamps make it more difficult to correlate events and can lead to an inaccurate analysis. Determining the correct time a particular event occurred on a system is critical when conducting forensic analysis and investigating system events. Sources outside the configured acceptable allowance (drift) may be inaccurate.

                        Minimizing the exposure of the server functionality of the chrony daemon diminishes the attack surface.

                        Note that USNO offers authenticated NTP service to DoD and U.S. Government agencies operating on the NIPR and SIPR networks. Visit https://www.usno.navy.mil/USNO/time/ntp/dod-customers for more information. false
                        Fix Text:Configure OL 8 to disable the chrony daemon from acting as a server by adding/modifying the following line in the "/etc/chrony.conf" file.

                        port 0
                        Severity:low
                        Weight:10.0
                        Reference:
                        Title:DPMS Target Oracle Linux 8
                        Publisher:DISA
                        Type:DPMS Target
                        Subject:Oracle Linux 8
                        Identifier:5416
                        Definitions:
                        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:def:302
                        Result:false
                        Title:OL08-00-030741 - OL 8 must disable the chrony daemon from acting as a server.
                        Description:Inaccurate time stamps make it more difficult to correlate events and can lead to an inaccurate analysis. Determining the correct time a particular event occurred on a system is critical when conducting forensic analysis and investigating system events. Sources outside the configured acceptable allowance (drift) may be inaccurate.

                        Minimizing the exposure of the server functionality of the chrony daemon diminishes the attack surface.

                        Note that USNO offers authenticated NTP service to DoD and U.S. Government agencies operating on the NIPR and SIPR networks. Visit https://www.usno.navy.mil/USNO/time/ntp/dod-customers for more information.
                        Class:compliance
                        Tests:
                        • false (All child checks must be true.)
                          • false (/etc/chrony.conf: port option is set to 0)
                        Tests:
                        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:tst:30200 (textfilecontent54_test)
                        Result:false
                        Title:/etc/chrony.conf: port option is set to 0
                        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
                        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
                        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ol8:obj:30200 (textfilecontent54_object)
                        Object Requirements:
                        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/chrony.conf'
                        • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*port[ \t]+0[ \t]*$'
                        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
                        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
